docs.abstract: Controversy over a video uploaded to Twitter over the weekend revealed old fault lines, and why social media is so good at exposing them.

docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Silicon Valley Hobnobs in Davos
headline.print_headline: Questions Persist About a Viral Video Perfect Storm

docs.abstract: Apple has disabled Group FaceTime, the feature that enabled the eavesdropping, while it works on a fix. But for extra security, follow these steps.
docs.snippet: Apple has disabled Group FaceTime, the feature that enabled the eavesdropping, while it works on a fix. But for extra security, follow these steps.
docs.lead_paragraph: A major bug in Apple’s FaceTime app surfaced on Monday that allows anyone with an iPhone, iPad or Mac computer to eavesdrop on other users without their knowledge. Apple said Monday evening that it was aware of the glitch, was working on a fix and would release it in a software update later this week.

headline.main: How to Disable FaceTime to Avoid Eavesdropping Bug
headline.print_headline: Best Remedy For FaceTime? Turn It Off

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker, which reported quarterly earnings, faces a number of issues, from consumer demand in China to an unusual security bug in its iPhone software.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker, which reported quarterly earnings, faces a number of issues, from consumer demand in China to an unusual security bug in its iPhone software.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple said on Tuesday that profits were flat and revenues were down in its most recent quarter, indicating a difficult road ahead for a company that five months ago became the first American firm to be valued above $1 trillion.

headline.main: Apple Says Profits Were Flat, Citing Slump in China
headline.print_headline: Slowdown In China Takes Toll On Apple

docs.abstract: Chinese factories, which have long made goods for the world, increasingly make stuff for the country’s own middle class. When those spenders hold back, local workers can suffer.
docs.snippet: Chinese factories, which have long made goods for the world, increasingly make stuff for the country’s own middle class. When those spenders hold back, local workers can suffer.
docs.lead_paragraph: HUOJIANCUN, China — The line to quit stretched the length of a football field.

headline.main: Apple Takes a Hit in China, and Workers There Feel the Pain
headline.print_headline: In China, Apple’s Slump Shrinks Workers’ Wages

docs.abstract: Angela Ahrendts, hired after leading Burberry to global prominence, was among Apple’s highest-paid executives.
docs.snippet: Angela Ahrendts, hired after leading Burberry to global prominence, was among Apple’s highest-paid executives.
docs.lead_paragraph: Angela Ahrendts, the former Burberry chief hired by Apple five years ago to oversee its stores, said Tuesday that she would leave the company in April.

headline.main: Chief of Apple Stores Is Leaving After 5 Years in the Job
headline.print_headline: Chief of Apple’s Stores Is Leaving In Unusual Departure for Company

docs.snippet: Moral panic about our use of devices could benefit from good data. Big Tech companies are sitting on that information.

docs.abstract: The cold war between Facebook and Apple over data use and privacy is heating up. How far should Mr. Cook take it?
docs.snippet: The cold war between Facebook and Apple over data use and privacy is heating up. How far should Mr. Cook take it?
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s nowhere in his job description, but Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has recently taken a moonlight gig as Facebook’s privacy watchdog.

headline.main: Maybe Only Tim Cook Can Fix Facebook’s Privacy Problem

docs.abstract: Also, the Fed makes a surprising announcement, and the true cost of the government shutdown.
docs.snippet: Also, the Fed makes a surprising announcement, and the true cost of the government shutdown.
docs.lead_paragraph: Which kind of Super Bowl watcher are you? One who A) cares about the actual game, B) is in it for the snacks, or C) wants to see how the $5.3 million ads stack up? That’s the top asking price for a 30-second commercial during CBS’s broadcast, although some spots are going for the relative steal of $5.1 million. (Oh, and if you’re wondering, I’m a solid C, plus B if spicy wings are available.) This is the first year in a decade that the cost of a Super Bowl ad hasn’t increased — NBC charged $5.25 million in 2018 — mostly owing to waning viewer numbers. You can drop that factoid when the cheese-dip conversation hits a lull, or any of the other business and tech tidbits you’re about to devour in this email. You can have a nachos-and-beer hangover on Monday and still be on top of the news.

headline.main: The Week in Business: Let the Apple vs. Facebook Battle Begin, and China Goes Soybean Shopping

docs.abstract: From Apple to Nvidia, tech companies say business is slowing. Among the reasons: China and a Bitcoin slump. It may be just a bump — until it’s not.
docs.snippet: From Apple to Nvidia, tech companies say business is slowing. Among the reasons: China and a Bitcoin slump. It may be just a bump — until it’s not.
